Visual Direction
Photography & Art Direction
Dark charcoal marble jars, silver spatulas, squared matte-black glass dropper. Every image should feel editorial â€” clean, minimal, studio-lit. Think Bynacht Ã— Aesop Ã— Sulwhasoo.

Shoot Direction for All Carousel Frames

The Superface packaging is dark and sculptural. It needs backgrounds that create contrast, not compete. No flat white. No busy styling.

  • Frame 1 (Product Hero): Single product, center frame, solid matte background. Warm sandstone for the serum. Cool grey concrete for the Elixir. Deep charcoal gradient for the 24K cream. One texture element only (cream swatch / serum drop / water mist).
  • Frame 2 (In Use): Model applying product â€” close crop on face/hands. Clean skin, natural dewy finish. Shot tight. No distracting backgrounds. Soft directional light. Can be UGC-style (phone-shot aesthetic) or editorial (studio beauty light).
  • Frame 3 (Benefits): Text-forward on solid dark or light background. Minimal typography â€” Cormorant Garamond for headlines, DM Sans for body. Max 3 benefit lines. One subtle product element in corner or bottom. Let the words breathe.
  • Never: Pricing on creative. Cluttered layouts. Gradients as background. Stock imagery. Flat white backgrounds. Multiple products in one frame (unless trio hero).
  • Always: Show texture (cream swatch, serum drop, micro-beads). Include the silver spatula in cream shots. Maintain the dark-luxury-meets-clinical tone.
Brand Reference Board: Look at Bynacht (dark packaging, moody studio shots), Aesop (clean minimal product photography, warm tones), Sulwhasoo (Korean luxury, model application shots), Tom Ford Beauty (dark editorial, black packaging pops). The reference images shown above in chat give you the exact tone â€” clean studio, sculptural product, no clutter.
